document.masterDocTitle: New species of Ameletus Eaton, 1885 and redescription of Ameletus longulus Sinichenkova, 1981 from the Russian Far East (Ephemeroptera: Ameletidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: New species of Ameletus Eaton, 1885 and redescription of Ameletus longulus Sinichenkova, 1981 from the Russian Far East (Ephemeroptera: Ameletidae)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Material examined . Paratype larvae (No 2971 a, collected together with the holotype ), Russia , Primorskiy Kray, Terneiskii region, Sikhote-Alin State Nature Biosphere Reserve, Poltkov Stream,
17 .VI. 1974
, Nadezdina.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 27–35 .
Ameletus longulus
, male imago: 27. Mesonotum, dorsal view. 28. Fore wing. 29. Hind wing. 30. Sternum IX, styliger and gonostyli. 31. Genitalia, lateral view. 32. Penis, ventral view. 33. Penis, dorsal view. 34. Penis, lateral view. 35. Subgenital plate, female, dorsal view. Scale (mm): 30–35=0.5; 28–29=2.0; 27=1.0

FIGURES 36–46 .
Ameletus longulus
, larva: 36. Labrum, dorsal view. 37–38. Apices of mandibles, dorsal view: 37–left mandible, 38 right mandible. 39. Labium, dorsal view. 40. Femur of foreleg. 41–46. Gills: 41. Gill I, 42. Gill II, 43. Gill III, 44. Gill IV, 45. Gill VI, 46. Gill VII. Scale (mm): 36, 39, 41–46=0.5; 37–38=0.2. The arrow shows the group of setae.

subSubSection.paragraph: Male subimago . Overall color brown. Wings whitish and translucent. All crossveins of fore- and hind wings bordered by brown. Terga brown, monotonous; terga VII–X darker. Sterna brown. Forelegs brown; middle and hind legs lighter; joints dark brown. Cerci dark brown.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 47–49.
Ameletus longulus
, egg: 47. General view. 48. Structure of chorion and small knob-terminated coiled threads. 49. Large knobs. The arrow shows the micropiles (mp).

subSubSection.paragraph: Distribution and biology . Russian Far East: Primorskiy and Khabarovskiy regions. Mature larvae and adults were collected in small foothill rivers.

Remarks.
A. longulus
was described based on young larvae, which, like all young larvae, have gills narrower than in mature larvae (Sinichenkova 1981 ). Kluge ( 2007 ) reviewed the genus
Ameletus
, and considered
A. longulus
as a junior synonym of
A. costalis (Kluge 2007 )
. Recently, we collected adequate new material associating the male, female, eggs, and larvae. The identity of our material was confirmed by comparison with photos of the denticles in the mandible and maxilla the paratype (number of preparate 2971 a) (kindly provided by N. Kluge). Herein,
A. longulus
is redescribed and new illustrations are presented, confirming that the larva illustrated by Sinichenkova ( 1981 ) is
A. longulus .

Matsumura 1931 : 1474 (
Chimura costalis
); Imanishi 1932 : 526–527 , Pl 31 fig. 1 , Pl 32 figs. 2–3 (
Ameletus sapporensis
=
Chimura costalis
); Imanishi 1933 : 65–66 , figs. 3,5 (
Ameletus costalis
=
Chimura costalis
=
Ameletus sapporensis
); Kluge 2007 : 257 (
Ameletus costalis
=
Ameletus longulus
).

Material examined. Japan , Nara Prefecture, Takami River,
23–25 .III. 1997
, T Tiunova,
8 male
,
4 female
imagines (reared), 12 larval exuviae.

Ameletus costalis
: male imago: 50. Mesonotum, dorsal view. 51. Tibia of foreleg. 52. Fore wing. 53. Sternum IX, styliger and gonostyli. 54. Genitalia, lateral view. 55. Penis, ventral view. 56. Penis, dorsal view. 57. Penis, lateral view. 58. Subgenital plate, female, dorsal view. Scale (mm): 50=1.0; 52=2.0; 53–58=0.5.

FIGURES 59–67 .
Ameletus costalis
, larva: 59–60. Apices of mandibles, dorsal view: 59. Left mandible, 60. Right mandible. 61. Femur of fore leg. 62–67. Gills: 62. Gill I, 63. Gill II, 64. Gill III, 65. Gill IV, 66. Gill VI, 67. Gill VII. Scale (mm): 62–68=0.5; 60–61=0.2. The arrow shows the group of setae.

FIGURES 68–70 .
Ameletus costalis
, egg: 68. General view. 69. Structure of chorion and small knob-terminated coiled threads. 70. Large knobs. The arrow shows the micropiles (mp).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Distribution and biology . The larval exuviae and the subimago emerged from the larvae were collected in a foothill river in Japan at the end of March. The subimagos emerged on a warm sunny day. The mature larvae crawled, half-submerged to large stones protruding from the water and molted to subimago. According to Imanishi ( 1932 ),
A. costalis
is one of the earliest-flying Japanese species of the genus
Ameletus
.

Remarks. Until now it was thought that
A. costalis
inhabited streams of the Russian Far East and Japan . Study of a new material shows that the japan-continental species
A. costalis
represents a group of species, including the Japanese species
A. costalis
s. s. and two separate continental species. The new species herein described,
A. khasanensis
sp. nov.
and the redescribed species
A. longulus
.
Ameletus longulus
was regarded to be a synonym of
A. costalis
, when
A. costalis
was accepted in wide sense, including the continental form (Sinitshenkova & Tshernova 1976 ; Tiunova & Potikha 2005 ; Tiunova 2006, 2007, 2009 ).

Discussion. The male imago of
A. khasanensis
sp. nov
is similar to
A. costalis
by its forewings, in which the crossveins between the C and R veins are dark brown and are bordered by brown ( Figs. 2 , 52 ); however, the male imago can be distinguished from that of
A. costalis
by the absence of spinules on the dorsal surface of the fore tibia and the structure of the penis. The male imago of
A. longulus
can be distinguished from
A. khasanensis
sp. nov .
and
A. costalis
by the color of forewings, which are brownish with all veins brown in
A. longulus
(
Figs. 28–29
). By the structure of the gills,
A. khasanensis
sp. nov .
,
A . longulus
,
A. costalis , A. formosus
Kang & Yang 1994 ,
A. atratus Kang & Yang 1994
and
A. montivagus Kang & Yang 1994
can be assigned to a group of species in which gills III–VI bear an anal rib far from the anal margin. The larvae of
A. khasanensis
sp. nov .
differ from those of
A . longulus
,
A. formosus
and
A. atratus
in the structure of gills I. In
A. khasanensis
sp. nov .
, gill I has no vestigial anal ribs (
Fig. 15
), in contrast to
A. formosus , A. atratus
[ Fig.1, 3 (Kang & Yang 1994 )], and
A. longulus
(
Figs. 41–42
), in which gill I has vestigial anal ribs. The larvae of
A. khasanensis
sp. nov .
differ from
A. montivagus
by the width/ length ratio of gill IV. In
A. khasanensis
sp. nov .
gill IV width/length ratio is 0.54 (
Fig. 18
), in contrast to
A. montivagus
, in which this ratio is 0.55–0.58 [
Fig. 2
(Kang & Yang 1994 )]. The larvae of
A. khasanensis
sp. nov .
differ from those of
A. costalis
in the length of the denticles on the right mandible (
Fig. 12
), in the absence of the group of setae on the dorsal surface at the base of the fore femora (
Fig. 14
) and the width/length ratio of gill VII (
Fig. 20
).
Ameletus longulus
is similar to
A. formosus
in the presence of vestigial anal ribs on gills I–II, but differ from this species based on the width/length ratio of gill IV. In
A. longulus
, gill IV width/length ratio is 0.55 ; in
A. formosus
it is 0.47– 0.49 (Kang & Yang 1994 ).
